text: - I am Dr. Karen Hildebrand with AWS.

- And I'm Biagio DeSimone
with Aqua Security,
and "This is My Architecture."
(upbeat music)
- Can you tell me about Aqua Security?

- Absolutely. So Aqua
Security has a CNAPP solution.
CNPAA stands for

Cloud Native Application
Protection Platform.
Now, basically what that means

is that we want to take
cloud native applications

and protect them through
their entire life cycle.

So that includes the
code that they come from,

that includes the
infrastructure they run on,

and that includes the
workload itself once deployed,
we want to make sure that it's secured
through its entire lifecycle.
- So Aqua's built on AWS,

but you're also providing a
solution for customers of AWS.

Can you tell us what are
the customer use cases
that are coming in your direction?

What are those customers
trying to solve for?
- Absolutely.
So as customers, you know, move to AWS,

really what we are trying
to help them do is not only
one, understand what they actually need
to secure for, right?

'Cause a lot of them
don't necessarily know
if they're coming from legacy environments
what to secure now in AWS.
Also, you know, many of them

will have compliance
requirements, et cetera,

so they might need to make
sure things are locked down,

they understand networking
behaviors, processes, et cetera
everything running in that environment.
So we're helping them understand this
in the new kind of cloud native way.

- Terrific. Well, let's
dive into your architecture.
- Absolutely.
So what we're looking at here
is both Aqua's SaaS solution.

And over here on the right,
a customer environment.

So what we are seeing is
Aqua SaaS, a solution,

will connect into the AWS
environment of the customer.

It will then, you know,
move into what we have here,

which is an EKS cluster, so
Elastic Kubernetes Service.
So we have the customer's applications
deployed here on EKS nodes.
And you'll also see

we have Aqua deployed
here on each of the nodes.
Now, Aqua is deployed as a DaemonSet,

which means that we are
automatically, our agent, right,

is scaled across all of the
EKS nodes in that cluster.
So you always have Aqua

sitting next to any of
your applications here.
Now, what Aqua can do

is because we are so close to
the workload and application,

we can see all these
different behaviors, right?
Whether those are kernel level behaviors,
whether it's networking,

whether it's processes occurring
inside the application,
we can see all of those.
That gives us tremendous visibility

and also the option to
choose to block those
if we, you know, see fit.

It's a really great
approach that allows you

to have really low latency,
have a response right away,

and have it really native
to the environment it's in.
We support all sorts of AWS environments
like Fargate, Lambda, EKS, ECS, EC2.
So we support all the different kinds
of cloud native workloads.
- Fantastic.

So in a containerized
workload for example,
what would be some of the trade-offs
that a customer might be considering?

Is there different ways of
approaching this problem?

- Absolutely, and Aqua
even offers a couple ways.

So there is the option for
an an Agentless approach,

which would remove the agent
that we are seeing here, right?
And would basically just be
a cloud-to-cloud interaction, right?
So that would basically allow Aqua

to still see that you
have workloads in AWS.

We're still able to scan
those and assess them,

but it doesn't give us the
ability to then block, right?
Blocking for a lot of customers

is the kind of thing that
they come for, right?
Lots of tools can scan.
Aqua is the one that can actually
help you go ahead and block,

which gives you the
prevention that you might need

from bad actors, et cetera,
in your environments.

- Yeah, understanding that
surface risk that you have

is, well, as the attack
vectors is really important
and then being able to react to them,

especially I would imagine
in specific industries.

Can you tell me, are there
specific industry motions
that Aqua Security most often sees?

Are there industries that
are coming to you most often?
- Absolutely.
So anyone who has applications
that need to have really high reliability
or are working with sensitive data, right?

So someone like financial
verticals, right?

They're gonna have really,
really strict requirements

as to where their data
can live, what it can do,
who can access it, et cetera.

And they need to be
able to one, stop people

from getting there if
they're not allowed to,
and also be able to report on that, right?
They have complex reporting requirements.
And so Aqua can not only help them
put that blocking in place

to ensure that only they
have access to what's there,
and then if there's anything, you know,

not really allowed going
on that we can stop it,

but also have that reporting,
you know, timeline for them,

so they can understand
what happens and when.
- So if you're able to do that blocking,

what happens to the
container during that time?

- So, the container
itself actually stays up.

That's one of the really
great things about Aqua
is that we're able to block the process,
or the behavior that's occurring,

but allow the application
to continue on its own

to make sure that only
the allowed processes

and allowed expected
behaviors are occurring.

So it really helps you keep
that business continuity
for those customers that need it.

- So, from a customer's
point of view, the benefit is

really that they have
their container available,
their application that's running is up,

and so they don't have that
impact to their end customer?
- Exactly.
- Fantastic.

Thank you for bringing your
architecture here today
and sharing it with us.
- It was my pleasure. Thank you.
